revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Fortescue Graham|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox military person |name= Sir Fortescue Graham |image= |image_size= |alt= |caption= |nickname= |birth_date= 1794 |death_date= 9 October {{Death year and age|1880|1794}} |birth_place= [[Tintinhull]], Somerset |death_place= [[Stonehouse, Plymouth|Stonehouse]], Devon |placeofburial= |allegiance= [[United Kingdom]] |branch= [[Royal Marines]] |serviceyears= 1808–1870 |rank= [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] |servicenumber= |unit= |commands= |battles= [[Napoleonic Wars]] * [[Walcheren Campaign]] * [[Peninsular War]] * [[War of 1812]] [[First Carlist War]]
[[First Opium War]]
[[Crimean War]] * [[Battle of Bomarsund]] |awards= [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] |relations= |laterwork= }} [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] '''Sir Fortescue Graham''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|KCB}} (1794 – 9 October 1880) was a senior [[Royal Marines]] officer, serving for 62 years and seeing active service in the Napoleonic, Peninsular, and War of 1812, and later in Spain, China, and the Crimea. ==Early life== Fortescue Graham was born in [[Tintinhull]], [[Somerset]], the son of Colonel Richard Graham, Royal Marines, (a descendant of the Grahams of Platten, [[County Meath|Co. Meath]]), and his wife, Catherine, the daughter of Captain Philip Walsh, Royal Navy. He was educated at [[Martock|Martock College]], Somerset.{{cite DNB|wstitle=Graham, Fortescue |last=Chichester |first=Henry Manners |authorlink=Henry Manners Chichester|volume=22|no-icon=1}} ==Royal Marines== He joined the Royal Marines when aged only 14, being appointed as a [[second lieutenant]] in the Chatham Division of the Royal Marines on 17 November 1808.{{Cite book|title=The Navy List |date=December 1814 |location=London |publisher=Admiralty |page=30 }} He remained in that rank for the next seventeen years, twelve of them in the artillery branch of the marines. He was with the composite battalion formed of marines of the squadron, which served with the army ashore in the [[Walcheren Campaign]] of 1809. Subsequently, he served with the [[Royal Marines Battalions (Napoleonic Wars)|1st Battalion of Royal Marines]]{{Cite book |first=Paul Harris |last=Nicolas |authorlink=Paul Harris Nicolas |title=Historical Record of the Royal Marine Forces, Volume 2, 1805–1842 |location=London |publisher=Boone |year=1845 |page=272}} in Portugal and in the north of Spain, including the capture and defence of [[Castro Urdiales]]. Graham proceeded with the 1st Battalion to America, and was present under [[Thomas Sydney Beckwith|Sir Sydney Beckwith]] at the [[Battle of Craney Island|attack on Norfolk]] and taking of [[Hampton, Virginia]] in 1814. When the brigade was broken up, Graham accompanied the battalion to Canada, and was sent in charge of a division of gunboats to attack an American battery at the head of [[Battle of Plattsburgh|Lake Champlain]], with which he was engaged several hours. Afterwards he returned with the battalion to the coast of America, and was present at the attack and capture of [[Battle of Fort Peter|Fort Peter]] and the town of [[St. Mary's, Georgia]]. He became a [[Lieutenant (British Army and Royal Marines)|first lieutenant]] on 6 May 1825, and after almost thirty years service as a [[subaltern]] was promoted to captain on 10 July 1837.{{Cite book |title=The Navy List |location=London |publisher=John Murray |date=20 June 1848 |page=62 |url=https://archive.org/details/navylist08admigoog |accessdate=12 October 2013 }} Soon after he joined the battalion of marines doing duty in Spain during the [[First Carlist War]], and subsequently went to China, where he commanded the marine battalion in the demonstration against [[Nanking]] at the close of the [[First Anglo-Chinese War]]. He was promoted to major on 11 November{{London Gazette |issue=21262 |date=11 November 1851 |startpage=2970 }} and lieutenant colonel on 26 November 1851,{{London Gazette |issue=21268 |date=28 November 1851 |startpage=3300 |nolink=yes }} and to colonel on 20 January 1854. In July–August 1854 Graham commanded a brigade of marines at the [[Battle of Bomarsund|capture of Bomarsund Fortress]], on the [[Åland Islands]], during the [[Crimean War]], and was made a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in July 1855.{{London Gazette |issue=21743 |date=10 July 1855 |startpage=2654 |nolink=yes }} He served as the [[Colonel Commandant]] of the Portsmouth Division of Royal Marines from 1855{{London Gazette |issue=21735 |date=26 June 1855 |startpage=2457 |nolink=yes }} to 1857, and as Aide-de-camp to [[Queen Victoria|the Queen]] from 1854{{London Gazette |issue=21572 |date=14 July 1854 |startpage=2195 |nolink=yes }} to 1857. He was made a major general in 1857,{{London Gazette |issue=21970 |date=24 February 1857 |startpage=615 |nolink=yes }} served as Colonel of the Plymouth Division from 1863,{{London Gazette |issue=22742 |date=5 June 1863 |startpage=2911 |nolink=yes }} was made a lieutenant general and a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] in 1865,{{London Gazette |issue=22952 |date=28 March 1865 |startpage=1731|nolink=yes }} General{{London Gazette |issue=23191 |date=27 November 1866 |startpage=6471 |nolink=yes }} and Colonel of the Royal Marine Artillery in 1866, and finally retired in 1870.{{London Gazette |issue=23603 |date=1 April 1870 |startpage=2005 |nolink=yes }} ==Personal life== Graham was married twice; firstly in 1828 to Caroline, the daughter of G. Palliser. After her death in 1859, he married Jane Mary, the daughter of Captain Lowcay, Royal Navy, and widow of [[s:Blight, William (DNB00)|Admiral William Blight]], she died in 1866. Graham died at his residence, 69 Durnford Street, Stonehouse, Devonshire, on 9 October 1880.{{London Gazette |issue=24899 |date=9 November 1880 |startpage=5636 |nolink=yes }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Graham, Fortescue}} [[Category:1794 births]] [[Category:1880 deaths]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:People from South Somerset (district)]] [[Category:Royal Marines generals]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the Crimean War]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the First Opium War]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the Napoleonic Wars]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the War of 1812]]
